main-text.text: 1.0 Purpose and Benefits
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The purpose of this Information Technology Policy is to provide information regarding the use of domain names by state government entities for public facing and intranet websites. This policy assures the assigned domain names appropriately reflect New York State government services and major programs. The use of the "ny.gov" domain provides for branding New York State government services available on the Internet and enables customers to readily recognize official New York State government entity websites.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 2.0 Authority
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 103(10) of the State Technology Law provides the Office of Information Technology Services (ITS) with the authority to establish statewide technology policies, including technology and security standards. Section 2 of Executive Order No. 117 1 provides the State Chief Information Officer with the authority to oversee, direct and coordinate the establishment of information technology policies, protocols and standards for State government, including hardware, software, security and business re-engineering. Details regarding this authority can be found in NYS ITS Policy , NYSP08-002 Authority to Establish State Enterprise Information Technology (IT) Policy, Standards and Guidelines.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: ITS has secured the domain "ny.gov" for New York State government entity use.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1 All references to Executive Order 117 refer to that which was originally issued by Governor George E. Pataki on January 28, 2002 and continued by Executive Order 5 issued by GovernorEliot Spitzer on January 1, 2007, Executive Order 9 issued by Governor David A. Patterson on June 18, 2008, Executive Order 2 issued by Governor Andrew M. Cuomo on January 1, 2011, and Executive Order 8 issued by Governor Kathy Hochul on October 8, 2021.
main-text.name: Footnote

main-text.text: 3.0 Scope
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy applies to all "State Entities" (SE), defined as "State Government" in Executive Order 117 or "State Agencies" as defined in Section 101 of the State Technology Law. This includes employees and all third parties (such as local governments, consultants, vendors, and contractors) that use or access any IT resource for which the SE or ITS has administrative responsibility, including systems managed or hosted by third parties on behalf of the SE or ITS. While an SE may adopt a different policy, it must include the requirements set forth in this one. Where a conflict exists between this policy/standard and a SE's policy, the more restrictive policy will take precedence.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.0 Information Statement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: All SE websites will use a standard domain naming convention which is determined and enforced by ITS.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.1 Domain Naming Convention
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: All domain names must:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Be easily understood and recognizable by the residents of New York State Clearly communicate the purpose of the site;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Be easy to type and avoid using confusing characters such as zeroes (0) in place of the letter "O" or the number one (1) in place of the letter "L" (l).
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Contain no less than 10 but no more than 36 characters, including the ny.gov portion of the domain name (the "dots" are considered characters - hence subdomains of ny.gov are to have at least 3 characters)
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Contain letters, numbers and dashes (-), but no other special characters such as underscores (_) and blank spaces;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Avoid the use of acronyms whenever possible, unless the acronym meets one of the following conditions:
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: a) The SE is commonly known by the acronym, or
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: b) The acronym represents a commonly known major program. Major programs may be multiple or single agency programs but widely known to the general public. This program naming option is not intended for small, targeted audience programs. Web pages for such smaller programs must be part of the SE's main domain name pages (e.g., www.health.ny.gov/flu);
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Refrain from using general terms such as "licenses," "recreation," and "benefits" without an identifier because they do not represent a specific agency/program origin or service. For example, "DriversLicenses.ny.gov" may be allowed. Statewide services that would be best represented by a general term would be an infrequent exception to this rule (e.g., desktop.ny.gov, login.ny.gov).
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Use short URLs over a separate or sub-domain address, for areas on the same website (e.g., use health.ny.gov/flu instead of flu.health.ny.gov).
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 4.2 Naming Patterns
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: 4.2.1 Naming Patterns Within ny.gov Domain:
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Within the ny.gov domain, the allowed naming patterns are:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: "nys_entity_name".ny.gov or
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: "program_name".ny.gov or
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: "application_name"."agency_name".ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: "program_name"."agency_name".ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: "nys_entity_name".ny.gov/"program_name" or
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: "Microsoft_AD_domain".ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.3 General Domain Requirements
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: In addition to the naming conventions, the following restrictions apply:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.3.1 No Non-Government Advertisements
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: A dot-gov domain and the ny.gov sub-domain, may not be used to advertise for private individuals, firms, corporations, or imply in any way the federal or state government endorses or favors any specific commercial product, commodity, or service.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.3.2 No Political or Campaign Information
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The dot-gov domain, and the ny.gov sub-domain, is for the sole operation of government, not for use in any political, political party, or campaign environment. No campaigning can be conducted with dot-gov domains. No dot-gov website may link, directly or indirectly, or refer to websites created or operated by a campaign or any campaign entity or political or campaign committee. Political sites, party names, or party acronyms cannot be used.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.3.3 Two-Year Eligibility Period
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: All dot-gov domains are registered for a 2-year period. During this period, a review of eligibility and administrative information is required. If necessary, the dot-gov Registrar will contact the Administrative Point of Contact (APOC) for domains. APOC information MUST be kept current. The dot-gov Registrar may request an updated authorization letter, updated Domain Name Server (DNS) information, or other information. This information enables the federal government to ensure dot-gov domains provide secure, official websites and promote the best possible service to the general public.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.4 Procedure to Request a Domain Name
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: SEs must obtain ITS approval before requesting any new third level domains (i.e., "agency_name".ny.gov or "program_name".ny.gov) using the form at https://on.ny.gov/domain-exception-request. ITS will review and respond to all requests within five (5) business days.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Page 3 of 6
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: Once a domain has been determined and approved, the appropriate ITS Customer Relations Manager can submit a Service Request ticket to initiate the work required for set up in the ITSM service catalog: Network Services > DNS Entry.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.5 Use of Approved Domains.
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: SEs should use only ny.gov domains. It is highly discouraged to use any other top-level domain unless the head of the SE explicitly determines another domain is necessary for the proper performance of an SE function. The use of any other domain runs the risk of the domain being lost or acquired by another entity. The ny.gov address ensures the public that it is an official state site and can be trusted.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: This requirement recognizes the proper performance of SE functions and includes an obligation for clear and unambiguous public notification of the SE's involvement in, or sponsorship of its information dissemination products including public websites. It also recognizes in certain limited circumstances other domains may be necessary for the proper performance of an SE function.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.6 Link Change Notification
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: When a link on a ny.gov Internet domain makes causes the user to leave a ny.gov Internet website, a notification or screen (i.e., a splash message) should alert users that they are leaving the official ny.gov Internet domain page. When a link on a ny.gov domain makes the user go to another ny.gov domain, a notification or screen (i.e., a splash message) should not alert users that they are leaving the official ny.gov Internet domain page because the user is still within the ny.gov domain. (e.g., governor.ny.gov linking to its.ny.gov)
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.7 New York State Government Entity Compliance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Effective immediately, all new requests for state government entity Internet websites, and requests for domain names shall use domain names as described within this policy.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: The following is required by all state government entities to be in compliance:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Use of a ny.gov domain name for the state government entity's main public web site;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · State government entities must retire their legacy domain names immediately.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Use of either ny.gov or the ITS approved ny.gov domain name for the primary website name must be provided on all documents, publications, correspondence, and public service information for the state government entity.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 4.8 Federal Government Compliance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The Federal Government can terminate or deny the use of an organization's dot-gov domain name where such websites are not operated in compliance with the conditions of use.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 5.0 Compliance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy shall take effect upon publication. Compliance is required with all enterprise policies and standards. ITS may amend its policies and standards at any time; compliance with amended policies and standards is required.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: If compliance with this policy is not feasible or technically possible, or if a deviation from this policy is necessary to support a business function, SEs shall request an exception through the Chief Technology Office exception process.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 6.0 Definitions of Key Terms
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Except for terms defined in this policy, all terms shall have the meanings found in http:/its.ny.gov/glossary.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Submit all inquiries and requests for future enhancements to the policy owner at:

main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Statewide technology policies, standards, and guidelines may be found at the following website: https://its.ny.gov/policies

main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy shall be reviewed at least once every two years to ensure relevancy.
